trial_identification.studytitle: Prospective Double-blinded Randomised Comparison of Profix Mobile to Fixed Bearing Knee Replacements

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: devices - Fixed bearing prosthesis Treatment: devices - Mobile bearing prosthesis
Experimental: Randomised group 1 - This study is looking at a group of patients with knee osteoarthritis or other pathology requiring total knee arthroplasty. This group of patients were randomised to receive either a mobile bearing prosthesis or a fixed bearing prosthesis.
Experimental: Randomised group 2 - This study is looking at a group of patients with knee osteoarthritis or other pathology requiring total knee arthroplasty. This group of patients were randomised to receive either a mobile bearing prosthesis or a fixed bearing prosthesis.
Treatment: devices: Fixed bearing prosthesis
Treatment: devices: Mobile bearing prosthesis

primaryOutcome.outcome: Visual pain analogue score - Participants asked to rate their level of pain on a scale
Range of motion - The range of motion of the joint was assessed in both flexion and extension
Activities of Daily Living - Questionnaire looking at how the intervention impacts of activities of daily living
X-ray analysis of joint alignment - Using X-rays, the knee was assessed for mechanical and anatomical alignment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - patients presenting to a single orthopaedic surgeon with knee pathology, who were suitable candidates for total knee arthroplasty
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- refusal to participate
- other simultaneous surgery
- post traumatic osteoarthritis
- prior open knee surgery

recruitment.hospital: Dr Dean Pepper, orthopaedic surgeon private rooms - Port Macquarie

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The University of New South Wales

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is a randomised control trial comparing two different prosthetic designs used in total knee arthroplasty. Participants were randomised to receive either of the two prostheses and then were followed up of a period of 7 years, looking at pain, range of motion and impact on quality of life. The literature and joint registry of Australia shows that one of the prosthesis may be inferior to the other. Our research team hypothesised that this was not the case and that previous elicited differences were related to other factors.
